div.head:
DUDLEY OBSERVATORY.
„From the Albany Argus, Jan. 11.“
div.p:
A very large assemblage of the friends and patrons
of science met at the hospitable mansion of Mrs.
Dudley, on Friday evening last, to welcome the dis-
tinguished astronomer, Dr. B. A. Gould, who has
returned from Europe. The object of his visit was
to procure instruments for the Dudley Observatory,
and to visit and inspect the principal observatories
of England and the Continent. He was received
with great kindness and cordiality by the most dis-
tinguished astronomers and men of science, who
everywhere manifested a lively interest in the efforts
now making in this city for the advancement of as-
tronomical science. He was commissioned to order
a Heliometer, a Meridian Circle, a Transit Instru-
ment, and Clock. The three last are to be completed
and delivered in this country by the 1st of August
next, and are to have modifications, additions and
improvements which will render them superior to any
hitherto constructed.

The construction of the heliometer has been con-
fided, we are happy to state, to our countrymen,
Messrs. Spencer & Eaton, of our own State, who are
about removing their establishment to this city, hav-
ing made arrangements for erecting extensive work-
shops and for the construction of every description of
astronomical instruments.

Governor Seymour read to the company a long and
interesting letter from Mr. Airey, the Astronomer
Royal of Great Britain, to Mrs. Dudley; and Judge
Parker another from Baron Humboldt, which we are
permitted to give to the public:—

—The necessity in which I
have found myself of returning to Potsdam has de-
prived me, my dear Dr. Gould, of the pleasure of ex-
pressing to you how much your last sojourn at Ber-
lin has revived the sentiments of affection and high
estimation that we have felt towards you for a long
time. I have wished to address you these few words
of adieu before you return to your native country,
where, from year to year, scientific effort is achiev-
ing so much that is worthy of admiration. That
which impresses itself most strongly upon the Eu-
ropean mind is that by the side of those who devote
themselves to the culture of the sciences are found
such examples of eminent patriotism and noble liber-
ality.

How could we fail to point out to public gratitude
the generosity of Mrs. Dudley, of Albany, who has
contributed so liberally to the erection of a noble ob-
servatory for astronomy, and who has endowed it
with a grand heliometer. Attached as I am by my
feeble efforts in astronomical geography to the study
of the science which you cultivate with so much suc-
cess, I beg of you, my dear sir, to offer to that esti-
mable lady the homage of my sentiments of grati-
tude, and assure her how much I applaud the happy
idea of attaching the name and memory of the bene-
factress to an institution for the progress of the sci-
ences.

My health, since your departure, has not been so
good, without, however, interfering with my duties.
Please accept yourself my affectionate regards, and
transmit them to our mutual friends, Dr. Bache and
Mr. Peters.

What a happiness was the return of Dr. Kane, af-
ter so many sufferings and noble achievements?
